channel.title: math.AC updates on arXiv.org
channel.description: math.AC updates on the arXiv.org e-print archive.

item.title: Tor algebra of local rings with decomposable maximal ideal
item.description: arXiv:2507.01784v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Let $(R,{\frak{m}}_R)$ be a commutative noetherian local ring. Assuming that ${\frak{m}}_R=$$I\oplus J$ is a direct sum decomposition, where $I$ and $J$ are non-zero ideals of $R$, we describe the structure of the Tor algebra of $R$ in terms of the Tor algebras of the rings $R/I$ and $R/J$.
item.dc:creator: Saeed Nasseh, Maiko Ono, Yuji Yoshino

item.title: A hierarchical invariant for line bundles and its applications in algebraic geometry codes
item.description: arXiv:2507.01859v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: We introduce the notion of hierarchical depth for line bundles on smooth projective surfaces, defined via filtrations by line subbundles with successive quotients supported on effective divisors. This invariant helps to investigate both the algebraic and geometric complexity of line bundles through discrete stepwise constructions. We study some of its basic properties, including functorial behavior under restriction to curves and compatibility with ampleness and base-point freeness. Applying this framework to algebraic geometry (AG) codes, we show that hierarchical filtrations yield natural code families whose combinatorial parameters (dimension, minimum distance) evolve predictably across the filtration.
item.dc:creator: Rahim Rahmati-asghar

item.title: Multiplicative Relationships of Subrings and their Applications to Factorization
item.description: arXiv:2506.24031v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: When studying the properties of a ring $R$, it is often useful to compare $R$ to other rings whose properties are already known. In this paper, we define three ways in which a subring $R$ might be compared to a larger ring $T$: being associated, being ideal-preserving, or being locally associated. We then explore how these properties of a subring might be leveraged to give information about $R$, including applications to the field of factorization. Of particular interest is the result that an order in a number field is associated if and only if it is both ideal-preserving and locally associated. We conclude with a discussion of how these properties are realized in the case of orders in a number field and how such orders might be found.
item.dc:creator: Grant Moles
